# Test of Simple CANSIM Data
This displays the job vacancy data

```{r vacancy}
source("../../../../../../Dropbox/Tweets Data/R/core.R")
vacancydata<-loadTABLE("../../../../../14100226")
plotdata<-vacancydata %>% filter(North.American.Industry.Classification.System..NAICS.=="All unemployed",
                                   Job.vacancy.statistics=="Unemployment-to-job vacancies ratio") %>%
              select(Ref_Date,GEO,Value) %>%
              mutate(Ref_Date=as.yearmon(Ref_Date,"%Y/%m")) %>%
  filter(GEO=="Alberta")
ggplot(plotdata,aes(Ref_Date,Value))+
  geom_hline(yintercept=0,size=1)+
  geom_line(size=2,color="firebrick")+
  mytheme+
  labs(x="",title="Unemployment-to-job vacancies ratio")
```

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:


# Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
